content: are you aware of someone/something being aware?

it becomes very obvious if you go to the opposite end and give yourself the task "try to not be aware" or "try to be less aware"

apparently, it is less obvious if you say "be more aware". but both are contingent on the same duality of the "doer" or the "one who is aware" or "the one who moves from a to b". effortless because none of it exists; you are never aware of any of it. you're never aware of not being aware and you're never aware of being more aware.

Awareness (or just meditation) is "curative" in the sense that it is never actually presently aware of separative thoughts like...

"improving awareness" - awareness can't be aware of an improved awareness because that goes across time "from A-B", and there isn't any hierarchy of awareness in which awareness is being aware of a higher or lesser awareness

"what im supposed to be doing (being aware)" - you have never been aware of a "doer" of awareness

awareness is never defined by what the thought is describing because it is being the thought or being aware of the thought. as a small koan to illustrate, if you try to "think awareness", the mind goes blank because awareness is "prior" and "fundamental" and so it can't "step past itself" in the sense that you can't be aware of something you aren't already aware of.

what seems to be happening is that the activity of meditation or "being aware" is bringing up thoughts/beliefs about awareness/meditation, like the idea that awareness can be improved over time, or that there is a "doer" of awareness.

Meditation is "letting these thoughts/beliefs be", in the sense that you don't try to figure out a strategy which helps you improve awareness, you only sit still and be aware without trying to modify or control anything. Being aware is effortless because you're always presently aware, "improving awareness" is itself the idea of effort which separates the present into the future. Awareness is not presently aware of "improving awareness", because that is an ideal in the future, not the present. There are thoughts about improving awareness, but those are also occurring presently in awareness itself. Being aware is simply not overlooking what you are already experiencing. Essentially, giving priority to what you already are, in spite of thoughts that try to convince you otherwise.
